title: Turn Claude Into Your Self-Directing Daily Engine
description: Set up a system where one phrase triggers Claude to interview you, choose tasks, and execute work autonomously across multiple projects.

cards.title: Build Your Self-Directing Claude Engine
cards.body: You'll learn to set up a system where typing "Let's start our day" triggers Claude to interview you, choose your most important tasks, and execute them autonomously. This workflow flips the usual AI relationship ‚Äî Claude asks YOU questions, then decides what it can tackle. Takes about 25 minutes to build, then saves hours daily.

cards.title: The Self-Directing Workflow Concept
cards.body: Most people micromanage AI with constant prompts. This system reverses that relationship ‚Äî Claude interviews you with three questions, then autonomously chooses and executes tasks based on your priorities.

analogy.text: Like having a personal assistant who starts each day by asking what's most important, then goes off and handles everything without constant check-ins

diagram.caption: One phrase triggers autonomous task selection and execution

source.author: Alex Finn
source.description: Overview of the self-directing Claude system

cards.title: Create Your Claude Project Structure
cards.body: Set up the essential folder structure that Claude will use to organize your work. Create a dedicated directory and three key folders inside it.
cards.code:
mkdir claude-daily-engine
cd claude-daily-engine
mkdir context inbox outbox
cards.codeCaption: Creates the workspace folders Claude needs to organize inputs and outputs
bullets: context: Your profile, projects, and reference materials
inbox: Tasks and inputs waiting to be processed
outbox: Completed work and deliverables from Claude

troubleshoot.label: Permission denied error
troubleshoot.error: mkdir: cannot create directory: Permission denied
troubleshoot.fix: Run sudo mkdir claude-daily-engine or choose a directory where you have write permissions like your home folder

cards.title: The Claude Rules File: Your AI's Brain
cards.body: The claude.md file is Claude's memory and personality. It contains your profile, current projects, working preferences, and instructions that Claude reads at the start of every session.
bullets: Your professional background and expertise areas
Current projects with priorities and deadlines
Work preferences and communication style
Available tools and resources Claude can use
cards.safe: This file stays local ‚Äî Claude only reads it when you explicitly share it in Co-work sessions
cards.cta: Ready to build my brain file

read.body:
The rules file acts as Claude's persistent memory across sessions. Unlike regular Claude conversations that start fresh each time, this system gives Claude context about who you are, what you're working on, and how you prefer to work.

Think of it as briefing a new assistant on their first day ‚Äî except you only have to do it once, and they remember perfectly every time you work together.

callouts.text: Keep your rules file updated with current projects. As priorities change, update the file so Claude stays aligned with your actual needs.

cards.title: Write Your Claude Rules File
cards.body: Create the claude.md file that will serve as Claude's instructions and your profile. This is what Claude reads first in every session.
bullets: Start with your role and expertise (e.g., "Senior Product Manager at TechCorp")
List current top 3 projects with brief descriptions
Add your work style preferences (communication, meeting frequency, etc.)
Include any tools or resources Claude should know about

source.author: Alex Finn
source.description: Example of setting up the claude.md rules file

cards.title: Quick Check
cards.question: What happens when you type "Let's start our day" in this system?

options.text: Claude immediately starts working on your last project
Claude interviews you with three questions, then chooses tasks to execute
Claude shows you a list of available commands
Claude creates a new project folder structure

cards.correctFeedback: Exactly! The system flips the usual AI relationship ‚Äî Claude becomes the interviewer, asking about your top priority, to-do list, and urgent items before autonomously deciding what it can tackle.
cards.wrongFeedback: The magic of this system is that Claude takes the initiative. It doesn't wait for detailed instructions or show menus ‚Äî it actively interviews you to understand your priorities, then makes decisions about what to work on.

cards.title: Launch Your First Daily Engine Session
cards.body: Open Claude Co-work, upload your claude.md file, and trigger the interview process. Let Claude take the lead.
cards.codeCaption: Type exactly this phrase to start Claude's interview process
bullets: Claude will ask about your #1 priority for the day
It'll request your current to-do list
Finally, it'll check for any urgent or time-sensitive items

source.author: Alex Finn
source.description: Demonstrating the daily trigger phrase and interview process

cards.title: Your Claude Engine is Running!
cards.body: You've created the folder structure, written your rules file, and triggered your first daily interview. Claude now has everything it needs to autonomously choose and execute tasks. Next, you'll see how it parallelizes work using sub-agents to deliver multiple assets quickly.

cards.title: Parallel Execution with Sub-Agents
cards.body: Claude Co-work can spawn multiple sub-agents to work on different tasks simultaneously. Instead of doing one thing at a time, it might draft a Twitter thread, research stocks, and plan YouTube content all at once.

diagram.caption: One conversation spawns multiple parallel workstreams

bullets: Each sub-agent focuses on a specific deliverable
All work happens simultaneously, not sequentially
Outputs appear in your outbox folder as they complete

initialMessages.content: Think about your typical workday. How many tasks do you juggle at once? What if an AI could literally work on 3-5 different deliverables simultaneously while you focus on high-level priorities? That's what sub-agent parallelization achieves ‚Äî turning your scattered task list into multiple focused work streams that complete at the same time.

cards.title: Monitor Your Outbox for Deliverables
cards.body: As Claude's sub-agents work, they'll deposit completed files in your outbox folder. Check it regularly to see what's been delivered.
bullets: Draft content appears as markdown or text files
Research data comes as organized documents
Strategy documents include actionable recommendations
Each file is clearly named with its purpose
cards.warn: Files may appear at different times as sub-agents work at different speeds

source.author: Alex Finn
source.description: Examples of parallel work output and file organization

cards.title: Quick Check
cards.question: What's the main advantage of Claude's sub-agent parallelization?

options.text: It makes each individual task higher quality
It completes multiple different tasks simultaneously instead of sequentially
It reduces the number of prompts you need to write
It automatically prioritizes tasks by importance

cards.correctFeedback: Exactly! Instead of waiting for one task to finish before starting the next, sub-agents work in parallel. This means a 15-minute conversation might produce a Twitter thread, research report, and content strategy all at the same time.
cards.wrongFeedback: While those benefits might occur, the core advantage is speed through parallelization. Think of it like having multiple people working on your to-do list simultaneously, rather than one person doing everything sequentially.

cards.title: End Your Day with a Summary
cards.body: Close each session by asking Claude to summarize what was accomplished. This creates continuity between daily sessions.
cards.codeCaption: Type this phrase to get a completion summary
bullets: Claude lists all completed deliverables
It notes any incomplete or ongoing tasks
Provides context for tomorrow's session
Suggests priorities for the next day

source.author: Alex Finn
source.description: End-of-day summary process and continuity setup

cards.title: Customizing Your Engine
cards.body: The beauty of this system is its adaptability. Change the claude.md file to change Claude's behavior without rebuilding the entire workflow.
bullets: Update priorities: Modify current projects as they evolve
Change work style: Adjust communication preferences or output formats
Add new tools: Include new resources or integrations Claude should use
Refine focus: Narrow or broaden the types of tasks Claude handles
cards.safe: All changes take effect immediately in the next session ‚Äî no complex reconfiguration needed

read.body:
The system's power comes from its simplicity. Your entire AI workflow is controlled by a single text file that you can edit anytime. Want Claude to focus more on creative work? Update the rules. Need it to handle different types of research? Modify the project descriptions.

This approach means your AI assistant evolves with your needs without requiring technical changes to the underlying system. It's like updating your assistant's job description rather than hiring a new person.

codeBlocks.code:
# Updated priority example
Current focus: Q1 product launch
Deadline: March 15
Key deliverables: messaging, competitive analysis, launch plan
codeBlocks.caption: Simple text updates change Claude's entire focus

cards.title: Quick Check
cards.question: How do you modify Claude's behavior in this system?

options.text: Rebuild the folder structure with new parameters
Edit the claude.md rules file with updated priorities and preferences
Create new trigger phrases for different workflows
Train a new version of Claude with different examples

cards.correctFeedback: Perfect! The genius of this system is that everything Claude knows about you and your work comes from that one text file. Update it, and Claude's behavior changes immediately in the next session.
cards.wrongFeedback: The system stays simple ‚Äî no rebuilding or retraining needed. Just edit the claude.md file like updating a document, and Claude adapts its behavior based on your new information and priorities.

cards.title: Test Your Complete System
cards.body: Run through a full cycle to verify everything works: trigger the interview, let Claude work, check outputs, and get an end-of-day summary.
bullets: Start with "Let's start our day" and answer the three questions
Let Claude choose and execute tasks autonomously
Monitor your outbox folder for completed deliverables
End with "end of day" for a summary
Note what worked well and what to adjust in your rules file

troubleshoot.label: Claude seems confused about my projects
troubleshoot.error: Claude asks for clarification on basic project details
troubleshoot.fix: Your claude.md file needs more specific project descriptions. Add current context, deadlines, and key stakeholders for each active project.

troubleshoot.label: No files appearing in outbox
troubleshoot.error: Claude mentions completing work but no deliverables show up
troubleshoot.fix: In Claude Co-work, explicitly ask Claude to save files to your outbox folder. It may need a reminder about your local file structure.

cards.title: Your Self-Directing Claude Engine is Live!
cards.body: You've built a system where one phrase triggers Claude to interview you, autonomously choose tasks, and execute them in parallel. You can now: start each day with a single trigger phrase, let Claude interview and prioritize your work, receive multiple deliverables from parallel sub-agents, and customize the entire system by editing one text file. Time to experience what Alex calls "80% of daily work done in 3 minutes."
